user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_strx_to_uint32_n_:
```c
size_t
MHD_strx_to_uint32_n_ (const char *str,
                       size_t maxlen,
                       uint32_t *out_val)
{
  size_t i;
  uint32_t res;
  int digit;
  if (! str || ! out_val)
    return 0;

  res = 0;
  i = 0;
  while (i < maxlen && (digit = toxdigitvalue (str[i])) >= 0)
  {
    if ( (res > (UINT32_MAX / 16)) ||
         ((res == (UINT32_MAX / 16)) &&
          ( (uint32_t) digit > (UINT32_MAX % 16)) ) )
      return 0;

    res *= 16;
    res += (unsigned int) digit;
    i++;
  }

  if (i)
    *out_val = res;
  return i;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
( (uint32_t) digit > (UINT32_MAX % 16))
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The fragment compares (uint32_t)digit to (UINT32_MAX % 16), and UINT32_MAX % 16 is the compile-time constant 15. The loop ensures digit >= 0 (digit is produced by toxdigitvalue), and the typical toxdigitvalue returns values in 0..15, so the subexpression (digit > 15) will always be false in normal semantics. That makes that right-hand operand of the && never true, but it simply makes that part of the conditional unneeded — it does not render any reachable statement in the function unreachable (no code is placed after a constant-true/false guard that would be permanently skipped). Thus Rule 2.1 is not violated.
